Package fr.cnrs.iees.uit.space

Basic geometric classes internally used by IndexingTree.

The main concept behind this once-again implementation of geometric entities is that we do not care about space dimension. All the classes here represent the same concept in a space of any dimension greater or equal to 1. Dimension is set at instantiation of these classes. This allows to implement QuadTree, OctTrees, k-d trees, with the same class no matter the value of dimension k. Ah, another idea is to keep all this as lightweight as possible -- there are plenty of geometric libraries all over the internet for more generic uses.

Point is a point of any dimension. The dimension is set when instantiating it: the number of coordinates passed to Point.newPoint(...) will determine the dimension. Box is a n-dimensional rectangular box defined by its lower and upper corners. Sphere is a n-dimensional sphere defined by its centre (a n-dim Point) and radius. Instantiation is made through static factory methods in each class. All instances are immutable, i.e. cannot be modified once constructed. The Dimensioned superclass handles the dimension information.

All these interfaces can be used without overriding. The static factory methods they provide enable you to completely ignore the implementation details, i.e. you should only manipulate the interfaces, not the underlying classes.

Author:
Jacques Gignoux - 12 ao√ªt 2021
  • Interface Summary 
    Interface Description
    Box
    A rectangular box in a n-dimensional space, aligned on coordinate axes.
    Dimensioned
    An interface for geometric objects that have a dimension in space
    Point
    An interface and a factory for n-dimensional points.
    Sphere
    A generalised sphere in n-dimensional space (also called n-sphere.
  • Class Summary 
    Class Description
    BoxImpl
    An straightforward implementation of Box.
    Distance
    Various ways of computing a distance NOTE: given the effect of rounding errors on number comparisons, it would be worth implementing a precision for comparisons / computations.
    Point1D
    An optimised implementation of a Point in dimension 1.
    Point2D
    An optimised implementation of Point in dimension 2.
    Point3D
    An optimised implementation of Point in dimension 3.
    PointND
    An implementation of Point in dimension n.
    SphereImpl
    A straightforward implementation of a Sphere.
